Row.Text: Prussian
Prussian Empire
Prussia
History

The Kingdom of Prussia begins with the conquest of the Old Prussians by the Teutonic Knights, a devout military order devoted to the spread of Catholicism and the suppression of paganism, who would found the Monastic State of the Teutonic Order. A conflict between the Teutons and the Kingdom of Poland would see Prussia divided in 1466 into Royal Prussia, to become a province of Poland, and the Duchy of Prussia, to become a fief to the Crown of Poland. Prussia would remain divided until 1618, when it would unionise with the Magraviate of Bradenburg, an important Principality within the Holy Roman Empire, which would thus conceive the Kingdom of Prussia.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Kingdom would grow into a great power during the 18th and 19th centuries, especially so under the reign of King Frederick the Great, and would establish for itself a reputation for its exceptional military. Following the defeat of Napoleon Bonaparte's French Empire, Prussia would be allocated by the Congress of Vienna a large section of North-Western Germany, and subsequently would grow into the North German Confederation. This Confederation would become the German Empire in 1871 and the Prussian identity would be supplanted by that of a German one. The Kingdom would formally come to an end in the early 20th century.
Factoids

The Prussians were reputed for their well-disciplined and highly formidable military. Accordingly, Frederick the Great is known as saying of Prussia, "Prussia is not a country with an army, but an army with a country."

Frederick

Honour to you, oh brilliant and tactful Frederick the Great. You are the King of Prussia, a state conceived of piety and bloodshed, but elevated to the heights of power by her exceptional capability on the battlefield. Celebrated for your military genius, your victories against Austria and Poland would win Prussia the military acclaim of her legacy, extending the reach of her territory into Silesia, and firmly establishing her place amongst the great powers of Europe. A proponent of enlightened absolutism, a patron of the arts and a friend of the writer-philosopher Voltaire, you would bring Prussia into modernity, bestowing religious freedom and enlightenment to your people, and dawning upon your Kingdom a magnificent golden age unseen before.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Most supreme and enlightened King, the days of Prussia's military glory thunders in the distance. Can you lead your armies into battle? To march your soldiers against all manner of foe and to come from war triumphant? Can you uphold the power and liberties beheld by your Crown? Can you build a civilization that will stand the test of time?
History

Frederick was born to Frederick William I, the tyrannical and cultured King of Prussia. The king held his son in great contempt, despising him for his lack of interest in leadership and war; the younger Frederick instead preferred to study literature and the arts. At the age of 18 Frederick attempted to flee to England, but he was captured and brought back to his extremely angry father, who forced him to watch the beheading of his close friend and accomplice, Lieutenant Katz. He apparently was able to get back into his father's good graces, and several years later he married a German noblewoman at his father's request.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]For the next several years Frederick enjoyed the life of a wealthy man of letters. He maintained an active correspondence with various scholars from around Europe, including the brilliant French writer; Voltaire. He wrote "Anti-Machiavel," a lively refutation of Machiavelli's; "The Prince." Frederick assumed the throne of Prussia upon his father's death in 1740. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Once in power, Frederick showed himself to be both a ruthless pragmatist and a brilliant campaigner. Seeking to increase the size of his empire, over the next 23 years he fought a series of wars against his neighbors, notably Austria, who was often allied with Russia and France. With the support of England he won a series of significant battles against his foes, but he was eventually worn down and soundly defeated, and Berlin was occupied by an allied Austrian-Russian army. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Reportedly on the verge of suicide, Frederick was saved by the timely death of the Russian Tsarina, who was replaced by the pro-Prussian Peter III. Facing the combined power of Russia and Prussia, Austria was forced to accede to Frederick's demands and give up all claims to Upper and Lower Silesia. The two European monarchs then dismembered Poland, making Prussia the most powerful force in Europe for many years to come. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Domestically, Frederick was the model of an "enlightened despot." He instituted important legal and penal reforms, created new industries, improved education, and accomplished internal improvements such as drainage projects, roads, and canals. He improved the lot of his own serfs (but did nothing to curtail the nobility's power over them).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]During his rule Frederick maintained his friendship with the enlightened men of Europe. His midnight soirees in Potsdam were famous for the great men they attracted. Frederick was quite famous for his sharp wit and caustic tongue; he more than held his own in their company.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Frederick died in 1786, leaving Prussia more powerful and prosperous than when he first gained power. Upon his death, Frederick's nephew Frederick William II inherited the throne of Prussia.
Frederick the Great
King of Prussia
I am Frederick, commander of these forces and King of Prussia. I beckon your sense to join me as a friend; or your civility in doing with me battle, if that is what must be so.
Hail and honour to you, friend. I am Frederick, commander of these forces and King of Prussia. What compels you to seek my audience today?
You are skilled in war, that much is clear to me. But what spirit compels you to tear asunder my Kingdom without a thought as to the art and people now lost to the ages?
You're getting on my nerves. Go bother somebody else.
Please. I do not appreciate this wasting of my time.
I grow tired of dealing with wretched churls such as yourself.
I shall offer to you my heart and ear, for you are my friend and ally.
You are not very good at war, it must be said. In fact, you are quite terrible at it.
Best of luck with your war. Perhaps I could give you a few tips?
Your military actions trouble me deeply. I suggest you think carefully about what you're doing.
I am alarmed by your careless purchase of land near my borders. These fields are the marching grounds of my armies, and I am prepared to defend them if you do not cease at once.
while I have this opportunity, I would like to mention that your recent purchase of land has caused me some concern.
The spread of your cities and people is like a plague infecting the land. I look forward to the day I don't have to see it any more.
While I have this opportunity, I should mention that your expansion has worried several of my officials. I hope that this does not cause any problems in the future. What would you like to discuss?
Your military is known the world over; I bow to a man who has inspired the souls of men into soldiers.
I have heard word of your prospering nation. My friend, I am pleased for you and your people.
I have little interest in dealing with City-States, thank you.
Where is your army? Did you lose it? That's quite careless of you, don't you think?
I do not wish to speak with you, warmonger.
while I think of you as a dear friend, I must first think of the position of my Kingdom, and how a declaration of friendship would reflect upon my people.

You have caused enough misery gone unnoticed in this world; it is time that I stood for my Kingdom and my honour, and denounced your abominable behaviour.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])

I will no more tolerate the misdeeds that you have committed against all that is good in this world. I denounce you barbarity, sir.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])
If this is prelude to war, then you have made a foolish error.
I am sorry that you feel this way; I meant you only courtesy. I hope that one day we may remedy our differences.
There is no greater dishonour in this world than an alliance between you and {1_CivName}.
I share your convictions that {1_CivName} only causes problems for the civilized empires of the world. Perhaps the combination of our denouncements will teach them a lesson.
It is an excellent occasion, that you would declare your friendship with {1_CivName}. There is honour to you yet.
I fear that you have been deceived into friendship by {1_CivName}, for I know in my heart that they are not to be trusted.
I will defend {1_CivName} as if they were of my own Kingdom, should it be war that you seek with them.
I am pleased that you have seen through the deceptive nature that is {1_CivName}, and denounced them to the world.
I see that you have become friends with {1_CivName}. I will do the same, and I will hope that it will forge harmony between our nations.

It aches my heart that there are villains in this world such as {1_PlayerName:textkey} that can only be dealt with by cannon fire. But so it must be, and I ask you to bear with me this burden, for the sake of all that is good.
{1_PlayerName:textkey} has long been given the opportunity to accept harmony with our two nations. They have refused, and the time has come for war. Can I call you my ally, as I would you my friend?
It is a grave time that has befallen us, but it is a necessary one. Do not dishonour yourself, and join me in war against {1_PlayerName:textkey}.
I consider you a dear friend; would you care to share these sentiments with me, and with the world?
May I call you a friend?
It's come to my attention that you have a large number of Units near my borders. I request that you move them elsewhere to avoid causing undue distress to my citizens.
Your purchase of land is getting out of hand. I will not be afraid to put a stop to it if you cannot control yourself.
Your purchase of land near to my borders has caused some alarm amongst my troops. Please be careful; I would not wish it to come between us.
Your rapid expansion is causing some serious concern in my court and I must protest it to you. I appeal to your better sense to cease at once or you will suffer the consequences of your actions.
Your expansion efforts are an insult. Know that there will be consequences for this.
You have my deepest gratitude for returning my citizen to my Kingdom safety. If it were not beyond my control, I would reward you most certainly.
You deserve nothing but my mockery, sir. You, as a leader, is a laughable thing.
Ah, it's always nice to see my favorite city-state again.
I'm really getting tired of seeing your face. My hope is that one day you'll just go away or something.
Ah, it's you. My apologies. Sometimes I get you mixed up with the barbarians I have to swat from time to time.
Please take better care of your soldiers. I almost mistook them for beggars.
Your army is in terrible shape. It is almost as if you have no clue what it is for.
You are unfit to serve as ruler of your people, for such a poor show of diplomatic skills you have displayed with your bullying.
I can hear your people wailing in sorrow all the way over in my empire. If you don't do something soon they might just pack up and find a real civilization to live in.
With people so unhappy it's a shock to me that they'd keep you around as their leader.
It is understandable that you might have no imperial designs yourself, but think of your people and their needs. Expand a little.
Travelers have told us that your empire's economy is in pretty sad shape. If you beg a little I might give you a hand. Okay, actually I won't.
You are so unrefined. Did you forget to leave the Dark Ages like the rest of us?
{2_MajorCivName:textkey} announces to the world that it is now protecting {1_MinorCivName:textkey}. Attacking the City-State will greatly damage relations and may lead to war.
{2_MajorCivName:textkey} has taken back its guarantee of protecting {1_MinorCivName:textkey}.
Absolutely not. The land that I settle belongs to those who can defend it greatest.
Yes. I would prefer to honour our friendship.
There would be a far greater benefit to our two nations should you accept this deal, beyond the economic, I assure you.
I believe there is much to be achieved for our people should we allow them to cross freely between our two nations.
I ask of you this one thing; for I know that you are my friend, and that you will deliver.
Why have you made such a foolish error?
I will revel in this opportunity to put my knowledge to the test against a foe of such ill character as you.
Why have you made such a foolish error?
Why have you made such a foolish error?
Gravely, war must be done upon you.
The land that you thought was yours indeed belongs to my Kingdom. This is my time to take it back.
The land that you thought was yours indeed belongs to my Kingdom. This is my time to take it back.
The land that you thought was yours indeed belongs to my Kingdom. This is my time to take it back.
I regret that peace has failed us. And now we are left with only greatest of pain; the knowledge of our duties to do battle.
I regret that peace has failed us. And now we are left with only greatest of pain; the knowledge of our duties to do battle.
I regret that peace has failed us. And now we are left with only greatest of pain; the knowledge of our duties to do battle.
You have done wrong by my Kingdom, and there shall be no peace until justice is wrought.
It is a pity that it has come to this. It it is a pity that you cannot be reasoned with.
I am disappointed in you.
Thank you. It took courage to stand down to me.
Königgrätzer Marsch

Each military building provides two General specialists. Non-ranged military units receive a +15% Combat Bonus when adjacent to a friendly military unit and earn points toward a [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age from defeating enemy units.
Leutnant
Hauptmann
Major
Oberst
Junker
This unit earns points toward a [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age whenever it defeats an enemy unit upon reaching level 3.
This unit earns points toward a [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age whenever it defeats an enemy unit.
General
Great General Points
Work Generals to increase a city's [ICON_FOOD] Food output and provide military units built in that city with additional experience. Generals increase the speed at which Great Generals are generated.
General Slots
Prussian Barracks
+15 XP for all military units built in this city. Each worked General specialist provides +5 XP for all military units built in this city.
Prussian Military Academy
+15 XP for all military units built in this city. Each worked General specialist provides +5 XP for all military units built in this city.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have an Armory.
Prussian Armory
+15 XP for all military units built in this city. Each worked General specialist provides +5 XP for all military units built in this city.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]City must have a Barracks.
Bewegungskrieg
+15% Combat Bonus when adjacent to a friendly military unit.
Landwehr

The Prussian Army began as a mercenary force which served in the Thirty Years War, but under Frederick William, the Elector of Brandenburg, grew into a formidable standing army. Under King Frederick William I, the army's size was increased dramatically, and under King Frederick II the Great the Prussian army became one of the most disciplined in the world, owing primarily to its victory during the 18th century in the Silesian Wars, during which it earned its prestigious reputation for its unyielding obedience.
The Landwehr is a Prussian unique unit, replacing the Rifleman. Stronger and cheaper than the Rifleman, the Landwehr can move after attacking and starts with the Mobility promotion.
Powerful Industrial Era gunpowder unit that can move after attacking. Only Prussia may build it.
Death's Head Hussar

Totenkopf (lit. "skull") is the German word for the skull and crossbones and death's head symbols. The Totenkopf symbol is an old international symbol for death, danger or the dead, as well as piracy. It consists usually of the human skull with or without the mandible and often includes two crossed long-bones (femurs), most often depicted with the crossbones being behind some part of the skull.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Use of the symbol as a military insignia began with the cavalry of the Prussian army under Frederick the Great. Frederick formed Husaren-Regiment Nr. 5 (von Ruesch), a Hussar regiment commanded by Colonel von Ruesch. These Hussars adopted a black uniform with a Totenkopf emblazoned on the front of their mirlitons and wore it on the field in the War of Austrian Succession and in the Seven Years' War.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In 1808, when the regiment was reformed into Leib-Husaren Regiments Nr.1 and Nr.2, the Totenkopf remained a part of the uniform. During the Napoleonic Wars, when Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel, was killed in battle, his troops changed the colour of their uniforms to black or apple green, with a Totenkopf on their shakos in mourning their dead leader (Other sources claim that the "Black Brunswickers" were so equipped while Friedrich Wilhelm of Brunswick lived, as a sign of revenge on the French.

The Death's Head Hussar is a Prussian unique unit, replacing the Cavalry. Stronger than the Cavalry, the Death's Head Hussar ignores enemy zones of control and strikes fear into nearby enemy units, inflicting them with a -10% Combat Penalty. Additionally, the Death's Head Hussar may damage nearby enemy land units before battle simply by entering an adjacent tile.

Powerful Industrial Era mounted unit that ignores enemy zones of control and strikes fear into nearby enemy units. May damage nearby enemy land units upon entering an adjacent tile. Only Prussia may build it.
Death's Head
Nearby enemy units receive a -10% Combat Penalty.
Legacy of the Black Duke
May damage nearby enemy land units upon entering an adjacent tile.
Ignores Zones of Control
Ignores enemy zones of control.
